name: Arkansas Museum of Natural Resources
remarks: Museum preserving and interpreting the history of oil and bromine mining in Arkansas

name: Arkansas Post Museum
remarks: Museum dedicated to the history of Arkansas Post, Arkansas's territorial capital until 1821. Located on the grounds of the Arkansas Post National Memorial (National Park Service)

name: Bull Shoals-White River State Park
remarks: Trout fishing destination above and below Bull Shoals Dam with over 100 campsites

name: Cane Creek State Park
remarks: Wooded lake along Bayou Bartholomew including a hiking trail and camping

name: Conway Cemetery State Park
remarks: Historical state park with no recreational services located on James Sevier Conway's (the first governor of Arkansas) former cotton plantation

name: Cossatot River State Park-Natural Area
remarks: Class III, IV, and V whitewater rafting river listed on the National Park Service's National Wild and Scenic Rivers System

name: Crater of Diamonds State Park
remarks: World's only diamond-bearing site accessible to the public

name: Crowley's Ridge State Park
remarks: Park built on the homestead of Benjamin Crowley, dedicated to the culture and history of the Crowley's Ridge region. Includes many structures built in the 1930s by the Civilian Conservation Corps and spring-fed Lake Ponder

name: Daisy State Park
remarks: Park nestled within the Ouachita Mountains on Lake Greeson near the Ouachita National Forest. Popular for camping, water sports, and fishing

name: Davidsonville Historic State Park
remarks: Historic state park preserving the abandoned frontier river town of Davidsonville. Interpretive tours and signs guide visitors through the historic community bypassed by the Southwest Trail in the 1820s. Fishing is available along three nearby rivers, with 49 campsites

name: DeGray Lake Resort State Park
remarks: Resort state park with championship rated golf course, 94 room lodge, and over 100 campsites

name: Delta Heritage Trail State Park
remarks: Rails to trails conversion of former railroad bed through Arkansas Delta lowlands, currently 14 miles (23 km), planned to be 73 miles (117 km)

name: Devil's Den State Park
remarks: Civilian Conservation Corps-built park in the Ozarks with lake, caves, swimming pool and several trails. Includes over 100 campsites, including cabins

name: Hampson Archeological Museum State Park
remarks: Museum displaying archeological artifacts from the Nodena site, an aboriginal village of the Nodena people dated 1400-1650 CE, and bones from the Island 35 Mastodon

name: Herman Davis State Park
remarks: Park surrounding a grave and memorial to Herman Davis, a U.S. sniper during World War I

name: Historic Washington State Park
remarks: Fifty-three buildings that preserve and interpret the architectural, cultural, and political history of a historic nineteenth century town.

name: Hobbs State Park â€“ Conservation Area
remarks: Large park in the Boston Mountains along Beaver Lake featuring trails, camping, and a shooting range.

name: Jacksonport State Park
remarks: Park containing the 1872 Jacksonport courthouse, preserving the culture and history of a former steamboat river town

name: Jenkins' Ferry Battleground State Park
remarks: One of three battleground sites from the Camden Expedition of the Civil War. Water recreation available on the Saline River

name: Lake Catherine State Park
remarks: Civilian Conservation Corps park created along the lake, resulting in a well-preserved natural shoreline. Park features cabins, campsites, nature programs, marina, hiking trails, and a sand beach swimming area

name: Lake Charles State Park
remarks: Lake is maintained and stocked with fish by the Arkansas Game and Fish Commission; also features camping, hiking, boat ramps and an interpretative nature center

name: Lake Chicot State Park
remarks: Largest oxbow lake in the United States; formerly the main channel of the Mississippi River. Park is located within a pecan grove within a bayou environment, offering 122 campsites, 14 cabins, swimming pool, boat shop/marina and interpretative visitor center.

name: Lake Dardanelle State Park
remarks: Two sites (Russellville and Dardanelle), including 74 campsites, boating, visitor center, and aquarium. Popular for bass fishing, including hosting many major tournaments.

name: Lake Fort Smith State Park
remarks: Large lake in the Ozarks offering 30 campsites, 10 cabins, a marina, swimming pool and visitor center

name: Lake Frierson State Park
remarks: Reservoir built along Crowley's Ridge known for fishing. Features seven campsites, trails, boat ramp and visitor center

name: Lake Ouachita State Park
remarks: Built surrounding a reservoir, the park features a marina, trails, restaurant, eagle tours, and interpretative information on three historic springs in the park vicinity

name: Lake Poinsett State Park
remarks: Popular with fishing enthusiasts, the park offers 29 campsites, trails and interpretative programs

name: Logoly State Park
remarks: Environmental education park containing mature oak-hickory forests, mineral springs and endangered species

name: Louisiana Purchase State Park
remarks: Boardwalk through a headwater swamp leading to a monument dedicating the point of beginning of all surveys of the Louisiana Purchase, which allowed for the westward development and expansion of the United States

name: Lower White River Museum State Park
remarks: Museum dedicated to the preservation and interpretation of culture, commerce and history along the White River in Arkansas

name: Mammoth Spring State Park
remarks: Park surrounding the large natural spring, offering fishing, boating and hiking, an Arkansas welcome center and museum

name: Marks' Mills Battleground State Park
remarks: Park commemorating Civil War battle, including exhibits and park area. Also a Red River Campaign National Historic Landmark.

name: Millwood State Park
remarks: Forested area surrounding large lake known for bass fishing, bird watching, hiking and camping.

name: Mississippi River State Park
remarks: Newest state park created within the St. Francis National Forest. Park currently includes campground at Bear Creek Lake and birding trail.

name: Moro Bay State Park
remarks: Park at the convergence of Raymond Lake, Moro Bay, and the Ouachita River with visitor center. Popular destination for fishing, water sports, hiking trails and camping.

name: Mount Magazine State Park
remarks: The park contains Mossback Ridge, including the peak of Mount Magazine, Arkansas's highest point. Park also contains The Lodge at Mount Magazine, cabins, trails, and a hang gliding area.

name: Mount Nebo State Park
remarks: One of three mountain state parks in the Arkansas River Valley, includes historic cabins, 14 miles (23 km) of hiking trails, and popular hang-gliding launch points.

name: Ozark Folk Center State Park
remarks: Located near Mountain View, Arkansas, it preserves the music, culture, and traditions of the Ozark Mountains. Hosts special concerts and regular folk music performances.

name: Petit Jean State Park
remarks: Situated atop Petit Jean Mountain in the Arkansas River Valley, offers trails, creeks, and geology throughout the forested mountains

name: Pinnacle Mountain State Park
remarks: Rocky Pinnacle Mountain emerges where the flat Arkansas Delta intersects the Ouachita Mountains

name: Plantation Agriculture Museum
remarks: Former general store serving a community of cotton farmers operating as a museum including over 10,000 artifacts. Grounds also contain farm machinery used on cotton plantations.

name: Poison Springs Battleground State Park
remarks: Preserves and commemorates the Battle of Poison Spring in the American Civil War, which was part of the 1864 Camden Expedition

name: Powhatan Historic State Park
remarks: Preserves a small nineteenth-century river port town on the Black River

name: Prairie Grove Battlefield State Park
remarks: Preserves and commemorates the Battle of Prairie Grove in the American Civil War. Park includes a museum, gift shop, and several historic structures from the period relocated to the site around a walking trail.

name: Queen Wilhelmina State Park
remarks: Lodge atop Rich Mountain offers 38 guest rooms and is surrounded by forested slopes with creeks, trails, and mountain vistas. Located along the Talimena Scenic Drive.

name: South Arkansas Arboretum
remarks: Arboretum and botanical garden owned by South Arkansas Community College with plants native to the Western Gulf Coastal Plain region.

name: Village Creek State Park
remarks: Large park in the eastern part of the state. Rises along Crowley's Ridge from the surrounding Arkansas Delta, includes lakes, twenty-seven-hole golf course, camping, and hiking. One trail follows the 1820s Memphis to Little Rock Road.

name: White Oak Lake State Park
remarks: Lake in the woods on the border between Bottomland hardwood forest and loblolly pine forest with diverse wildlife. Camping, boating, fishing, and hiking are popular around the lake. Interpretative signs about the Red River Campaign in the area during the Civil War.
